results.title: For France, American Vines Still Mean Sour Grapes
results.abstract: French authorities have tried to outlaw hardy American hybrids for 87 years. But climate change and the natural wine movement are giving renegade winemakers a lift.

multimedia.caption: A tasting of forbidden wines at Hervé Garnier’s “Memory of the Vine” association in the village of Beaumont. Mr. Garnier, standing third from right, is one of the last stragglers in a long-running struggle against the French wine establishment and its allies in Paris.
multimedia.copyright: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times

results.title: Palestinians Finally Have Vaccines. But Will People Take Them?
results.abstract: For months, the Palestinian authorities struggled to get doses. Now they have the shots, but disinformation and conspiracy theories have led to widespread hesitancy.

multimedia.caption: Lining up to receive vaccines in the West Bank city of Bethlehem on Thursday. The Palestinian authorities face a challenge in persuading a majority of the public to get the shots.

results.title: As the Taliban Tighten Their Grip, Fears of Retribution Grow
results.abstract: Taliban leaders have promised amnesty to Afghan officials and soldiers, but there are increasing reports of detentions, disappearances and even executions.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: Taliban fighters outside the United States Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, last week. As the Americans withdraw their forces, many Afghans fear reprisal attacks from the Taliban.

results.title: A Journey Through Kabul on the Day of the Fall
results.abstract: A Times correspondent who grew up in the Afghan capital returned before the Taliban’s victory, taking in the end of one era and the fearful start of another.

results.title: All in or All Out? Biden Saw No Middle Ground in Afghanistan.
results.abstract: President Biden’s reductionist formula has prompted a debate over whether the mayhem in Kabul was inevitable or the result of a failure to consider other options.

results.title: Britons, Unfazed by High Covid Rates, Weigh Their ‘Price of Freedom’
results.abstract: Britain is reporting more than 30,000 new coronavirus cases a day, but the public seems to have moved on. Experts say this could be a glimpse into the future for other countries.
results.byline: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle

multimedia.caption: Concertgoers on Friday at the Reading Music Festival in Reading, England. “We don’t seem to care that we have these really high infection rates,” said Tim Spector, a professor of genetic epidemiology at King’s College London.

Concertgoers on Friday at the Reading Music Festival in Reading, England. “We don’t seem to care that we have these really high infection rates,” said Tim Spector, a professor of genetic epidemiology at King’s College London.

results.title: Myanmar’s Monks, Leaders of Past Protests, Are Divided Over the Coup
results.abstract: Some senior members of the Buddhist clergy have given their blessing to the generals in power. But hundreds of lower-ranking monks have been jailed for protesting.
des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

multimedia.caption: Monks in Mandalay, Myanmar, protesting in February against the army’s takeover. “C.R.P.H.” refers to opposition politicians whom the military had prevented from taking office.

results.title: After Airport Bombing, an Afghan Family Buries a Father, and Hope
results.abstract: The former police officer, from the Hazara ethnic minority, had hoped to help his family escape the Taliban. Instead, he is now numbered among the scores killed at the Kabul airport.
results.byline: By Matthieu Aikins and Victor J. Blue For The New York Times
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: Giant Puppet Ruffles Some Feathers on a Long Walk Through Greece
results.abstract: “Little Amal” is on a 5,000-mile journey from Turkey to Britain to highlight the plight of Syrian refugees. But in Greece, some have objected to her presence, saying it could encourage more migrants.
results.byline: By Niki Kitsantonis and Alex Marshall
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

multimedia.caption: “Little Amal” last month in Gaziantep, Turkey, at the start of her 5,000-mile journey. She “walks” with the help of a team of puppeteers.

results.abstract: As Afghans flee the Taliban, the experiences of a fellow countryman, Saidullah Karimi, warn of tough times ahead, but also carry a message of hope.

results.title: China’s Celebrity Culture Is Raucous. The Authorities Want to Change That.
results.abstract: The Communist Party has declared war on idol worship, part of a broader crackdown on what it sees as toxic celebrity culture that is poisoning the minds of the country’s youth.
results.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson, Amy Chang Chien and Cao Li

multimedia.caption: Zheng Shuang performing last year in Nanjing, China. A regulator accused the actress of tax evasion and ordered broadcasters to stop showing content that she has appeared in.

results.title: How Rodrigo Duterte Can Stay No. 1 by Becoming No. 2
results.abstract: The president of the Philippines says he’ll run for the vice presidency next year. Critics see a plot to avoid prosecution for the killings in his drug war.

results.title: Overlooked No More: Randy Snow, Paralympic Champion of Wheelchair Tennis
results.abstract: He won gold medals in singles and doubles at the 1992 Games in Barcelona and was the first Paralympic athlete to be inducted into the Olympic Hall of Fame.

results.title: He was a baby on 9/11. Now he’s one of the last casualties of America’s longest war.
results.abstract: Rylee McCollum, barely older than the war itself, had a wife and a baby on the way. He was one of the first publicly identified American victims of the suicide bombing at Kabul’s airport.
results.byline: By Jack Healy and Dave Philipps
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Lance Cpl. Rylee McCollum, a U.S. Marine, was killed in the suicide bombing at the Kabul airport in Afghanistan on Thursday.

results.title: A study confirms a small risk of blood clots after vaccines, but not as high as the risk Covid brings.
results.abstract: The study adds to the growing evidence that though the coronavirus vaccines are associated with certain rare side effects, those risks are dwarfed by the risks from Covid-19.

results.title: Italian Official Resigns After Uproar Over Honoring Mussolini’s Brother
results.abstract: Claudio Durigon, a member of the right-wing League party and a deputy economy minister, had proposed to rename a park after Benito Mussolini’s brother.
results.byline: By Emma Bubola and Gaia Pianigiani

multimedia.caption: Claudio Durigon, an under secretary in the economy ministry, has resigned over his controversial proposal to rename a park after the fascist brother of the former dictator Benito Mussolini.

results.title: Fossils Seized in Police Raid Demystify a Prehistoric Flying Reptile
results.abstract: Among the 3,000 fossils seized at a Brazilian port in 2013 was an almost complete skeleton from the pterosaur species Tupandactylus navigans, preserved in six limestone slabs.

multimedia.caption: An interpretative reconstruction of the pterosaur, based on the fossil recovered by the Brazilian police in 2013.

results.title: India hits a vaccination milestone, giving at least one shot to more than half of its eligible population.
